THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      In the Matter of Charleston County Magistrate James B. Gosnell, Jr., Respondent.
    
  


Opinion No. 26052
Submitted June 24, 2005 - Filed October 24, 2005

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Robert E. Bogan, Assistant Deputy Attorney General, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        Lionel S. Lofton, of Lofton & Lofton, PC, and Andrew J. Savage, II, of Savage & Savage, PA, both of Charleston, for respondent.Â Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a confidential admonition, public reprimand, or definite suspension not to exceed sixty (60) days pursuant to Rule 7, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR. The facts as set forth in the Agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS

I.
At approximately 9:15 p.m. on November 8, 2003, Joseph S. Mendelsohn, a Charleston Municipal Court Judge, was arrested for driving under the influence (DUI) in Mount Pleasant.Â  Judge Mendelsohn was also charged with having an open container in his vehicle in violation of South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 61-6-4020 (Supp. 2004).Â  
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 22-5-530 (Supp. 2004) provides that a person charged with a magistrate or municipal court offense may deposit a sum of money not to exceed the maximum fine with the magistrate, municipal judge, jail, or detention center in lieu of entering into a recognizance.Â  This provision is applicable, however, only in those jurisdictions which adopt the procedure.Â  The City of Charleston and the Charleston County Sheriffâ€™sâ€™ Department, which operates the Charleston County Detention Facility, use this procedure for DUI cases.Â  As of November 2003, Mount Pleasant had not adopted this procedure.Â  
Judge Mendelsohn was transported to the Mount Pleasant Police Department for paperwork and administration of a Datamaster test.Â  While there, Judge Mendelsohn learned that, under procedures established by the Mount Pleasant Chief Municipal Judge, the bond for DUI was $1,002.00, but that bond could not be posted at that time.Â  Instead, under the established procedures, Judge Mendelsohn would be transferred to the Charleston County Detention Facility where he would remain until a bond hearing could be held the next morning at approximately 8:00 a.m.Â  
Judge Mendelsohn knew the Mount Pleasant procedure was not the same procedure used in Charleston for DUI cases.Â  He questioned the arresting officer, a sergeant, and a lieutenant about the procedure.
Judge Mendelsohn telephoned a Mount Pleasant municipal judge.Â  After the municipal judge discussed the bond policy with the police sergeant, he explained the policy to Judge Mendelsohn. 
Thereafter, Judge Mendelsohn telephoned respondent, a Charleston County Magistrate.Â  Respondent, who was familiar with the procedure used in Charleston, asked the lieutenant why Judge Mendelsohn could not be released.Â  After the lieutenant explained Mount Pleasantâ€™s bond procedure, respondent remarked that he would go to the bond court and conduct a bond hearing for Judge Mendelsohn that night.Â  Respondent asked that Judge Mendelsohn be brought directly to bond court rather than first being booked into the detention center.Â  The lieutenant refused to bypass the standard booking procedure, stating respondent would be booked like any defendant.Â  The lieutenant then advised the arresting officer that respondent would be at the Charleston County Detention Center to conduct a bond hearing.Â  
Respondent telephoned the Summary Court Director to inquire whether she could arrange for staff to meet him at the detention center to hold a bond hearing.Â  During the conversation, respondent and the Summary Court Director discussed that if a bond hearing was held at other than normal operating hours, respondent would be required to hold a bond hearing for all incarcerated defendants.Â  Respondent elected not to call in staff to hold bond hearings.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Respondent met the arresting officer and Judge Mendelsohn at the detention center.Â  At some point, respondent took possession of the ticket, placed a â€œbond hearingâ€ stamp on the back, and entered the amount of $1,002.00.Â  When detention center officials expressed concerns over Judge Mendelsohnâ€™s release, respondent remarked â€œthis didnâ€™t happen until 8:00 a.m.,â€ or words of similar import and effect.Â  Respondent acknowledges it was his intention to facilitate Judge Mendelsohnâ€™s release without waiting for the morning bond hearing and to make it appear that Judge Mendelsohnâ€™s bond was set at 8:00 a.m. in accordance with Mount Pleasantâ€™s bond procedure.Â  
Respondent communicated his setting of the bond to the Mount Pleasant Chief Judge and asked the judge to indicate his approval of the bond.Â  The Mount Pleasant Chief Judge called the Charleston County Detention Center and was advised that officers were in possession of a valid bond set by respondent.Â  The Mount Pleasant Chief Judge told the officers that, since a bond had been set, the bond procedure he had established did not apply.Â  Judge Mendelsohn was released from the Charleston County Detention Center at approximately 2:30 a.m.Â  
Contrary to the published directives of the Chief Justice, respondent did not undertake to set bonds for the other detainees in the detention center.Â  See Chief Justiceâ€™s Administrative Order of November 28, 2000, revised July 1, 2001.Â  
II.
On November 6, 2003, respondent presided over a bond reduction hearing.Â  Respondent represents he knew the defendant, the defendantâ€™s father, and the defendantâ€™s grandfather.Â  
Respondent represents that when the defendant, an African-American, appeared in court for the bond hearing, respondent recalled a statement made to him by a veteran African American sheriffâ€™s deputy that â€œthere are four kinds of people in this world - black people, white people, red necks, and n_____.â€ Â Respondent alleges he repeated this statement to the defendant in an ill-considered effort to encourage him to recognize and change the path he had chosen in life.Â  Â Â 
LAW
By his misconduct, respondent agrees he has violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold integrity of the judiciary); Canon 1(A) (judge should participate in establish, maintaining, and enforcing high standards of conduct and shall personally observe those standards so that the integrity and independence of the judiciary will be preserved); Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety and the appearance of impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall respect and comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary); Canon 2B (judge shall not allow family, social, political or other relationships to influence the judge's judicial conduct or judgment); Canon 3 (judge shall perform the duties of judicial office impartially and diligently); Canon 3(B)(5) (judge shall not, in the performance of judicial duties, by words or conduct manifest bias or prejudice, including but not limited to bias or prejudice based upon race); Canon 3B(7) (judge shall not initiate, permit, or consider ex parte communications, or consider other communications made to the judge outside the presence of the parties concerning a pending proceeding); and Canon 3B(8) (judge shall dispose of all judicial matters promptly, efficiently, and fairly).Â  Â By violating the Code of Judicial Conduct, respondent admits he has also violated the following provisions of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR:Â  Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a judge to violate the Code of Judicial Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(7) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a judge to willfully violate a valid order issued by a court of this state).Â Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION 

We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent.Â  Standing alone, respondentâ€™s failure to comply with the Chief Justiceâ€™s Administrative Order would not necessitate imposition of a public reprimand.Â  Combined, however, with respondentâ€™s favoritism towards Judge Mendelsohn and his racial remark, the Court deems a public reprimand appropriate.Â  Accordingly, respondent is hereby reprimanded for his misconduct.Â  
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Karl Bryant Allen, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26053
Submitted September 12, 2005 - Filed October 24, 2005

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to issuance of a letter of caution, an admonition, or a public reprimand and to the imposition of other requirements.Â  We accept the agreement. The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Matter I
On or about August 24, 2000, respondent received a Covenant Not to Execute and a settlement check from opposing counsel to settle a portion of a claim for damages arising out of the death of respondentâ€™s clientâ€™s son.Â  The probate judge approved the settlement at a hearing on August 24, 2000.Â  Thereafter, on September 12, 2000, the probate court judge signed a written order approving the settlement and the clientâ€™s agreement to sign a Covenant Not to Execute.Â  The client timely executed the Covenant Not to Execute, however, the original document was misplaced and was not received by opposing counsel.Â Â  
Respondent delayed in responding to opposing counselâ€™s requests that the executed Covenant Not to Execute be returned to him.Â  Opposing counsel filed a Motion to Compel respondent to either provide the executed covenant or return the settlement check.Â  Respondent did not appear at the February 26, 2001 Motion to Compel hearing before the circuit court.Â  Respondent states he has no recollection of receiving notice of this hearing.Â  
On February 27, 2001, the circuit court judge issued an order commanding respondent to deliver to opposing counsel the executed Covenant Not to Execute within ten days. Â The order also commanded respondent to pay opposing counsel $500.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees within thirty days.Â  Respondent neither appealed the order nor filed a motion for reconsideration.Â  Respondent did not comply with the order to deliver the signed Covenant Not to Execute or to pay opposing counselâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
On March 19, 2001, opposing counsel filed a Rule to Show Cause why respondent had failed to comply with the February 27, 2001 order. Respondent failed to appear at the March 30, 2001 Rule to Show Cause hearing.Â  The circuit court judge found no valid reason why respondent had not delivered the executed covenant to opposing counsel and directed the Clerk of Court to execute the covenant.Â  Respondent subsequently paid the court-ordered attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Respondent failed to timely respond to ODCâ€™s inquiries in this matter. 
Matter II
A client alleged respondent failed to competently and diligently represent him. Â He further alleged respondent failed to adequately communicate with him about his pending legal matter.Â  
Full investigation by ODC revealed no evidence to support the clientâ€™s allegations.Â  However, respondent failed to timely respond to ODCâ€™s inquiries in this matter.Â Â  
Matter III
Respondent represented Mr. Doe in a number of legal matters.Â  In 1999, Mrs. Doe consulted respondent about a potential personal injury claim arising from a dog bite.Â  Mrs. Doe alleged respondent accepted her case and a $100.00 check for costs.Â  
Respondent denied accepting Mrs. Doeâ€™s case.Â  The disciplinary investigation revealed no evidence indicating respondent accepted Mrs. Doeâ€™s case.Â  Respondent represents the $100.00 check, which was from Mr. Doe, was for a legal matter for Mr. Doe and unrelated to the dog bite matter.Â  Â 
Respondent admits his records were insufficient to determine for which of Mr. Doeâ€™s cases the check was written.Â  Respondent also admits he could have taken steps to insure that Mrs. Doe understood he did not accept her dog bite case.Â  
Matter IV
Respondent entered into a deferred disciplinary agreement to resolve the three matters discussed above.Â  In that deferred disciplinary agreement, respondent admitted to violations of the Rules of Professional Conduct and agreed to comply with certain terms and conditions.Â  In the deferred disciplinary agreement, respondent stated that, due to injuries he sustained in an automobile accident and as a result of the terminal illness of his law partner, he did not devote sufficient attention to the management of his office and he was unable to diligently handle the volume of cases he had accepted.Â  In the deferred disciplinary agreement, respondent proposed to retain the services of a law office management advisor, meet with the advisor on stated occasions, and to insure that the advisor filed timely reports with the Commission on Lawyer Conduct (the Commission).Â  Respondent agreed that his willful failure to comply with the terms of the deferred disciplinary agreement would constitute misconduct under the Rules of Professional Conduct and constitute grounds for discipline.Â  The deferred disciplinary agreement was accepted by the Investigative Panel of the Commission on January 16, 2004.Â  
Respondent admits he failed to comply with the terms and conditions of the deferred disciplinary agreement.Â  In particular, he failed to meet with his law office management advisor in accordance with specific provisions of the agreement and he failed to insure the advisor filed the reports required by the agreement.Â  Following respondentâ€™s noncompliance, the Investigative Panel terminated deferment of the discipline.Â Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing client); Rule 3.2 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to expedite litigation consistent with interests of the client); Rule 3.4(c) (lawyer shall not knowingly disobey obligation under the rules of a tribunal); Rule 8.1(b) (lawyer shall not fail to respond to lawful demand for information from disciplinary authority); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct); and 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct), Rule 7(a)(3) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to knowingly fail to respond to a lawful demand from a disciplinary authority), and Rule 7(a)(9)it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to willfully fail to comply with the terms of a finally accepted deferred disciplinary agreement). Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.[1]
Additionally, within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall retain the services of a law office management advisor.Â  The advisor must be a member in good standing with the South Carolina Bar and his or her services must be approved by ODC.Â  Respondent shall be responsible for the fees and costs associated with hiring the advisor. 
The services of the advisor shall include the following:

  
    
      
        1.  
         An initial review and assessment of respondentâ€™s law office management systems, including identification of problem areas and recommendations for improvement;
      
      
        
        
      
      
        2.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Walter W. Brooks, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26057
Heard September 22, 2005 - Filed October 24, 2005

INDEFINITE
SUSPENSION


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster and J. Emory Smith, Jr., Assistant Deputy Attorney General, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, a Panel of the Commission on Lawyer Conduct (the Panel) found that Walter W. Brooks (Respondent) violated Rules 7(a)(1), 7(a)(3), 7(a)(4), 7(a)(5), and 7(a)(7) of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, as well as Rule 8.4 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR.Â  The Panel recommended that Respondent receive an indefinite suspension from the practice of law, retroactive to the date of his 1996 definite suspension, and that Respondent pay the costs of this action.Â  We agree.
Factual/Procedural Background
In 1980, Respondent was disbarred from the practice of law for failing to obey a police order in violation of the â€œblue light law,â€ for causing an affidavit to be prepared which misrepresented the incident, for having knowledge that this affidavit was fraudulently notarized, and for financing a drug deal for a client.Â  In re Brooks, 274 S.C. 601, 604-607, 267 S.E.2d 74, 75-77 (1980).Â  Respondent was reinstated to the practice of law in 1989.Â  In re Brooks, 298 S.C. 13, 13, 377 S.E.2d 827, 827 (1989).Â  According to court records, Respondent was the first attorney in South Carolina to be reinstated following disbarment.
In October of 1996, Respondent was suspended from the practice of law for nine months.Â  In re Brooks, 324 S.C. 105, 107, 477 S.E.2d 98, 99 (1996).Â  Respondent was suspended for making threatening and harassing phone calls to a clientâ€™s husband, making lewd comments to a client while inebriated in his [Respondentâ€™s] office, and serving a deposition notice on a party known to be represented by counsel when there was no discovery order.Â  Id. 
In addition, the Court ordered Respondent to submit to monthly substance abuse testing during the first year following his suspension. Â Id. at 108, 477 S.E.2d at 99.Â  Following the first year, Respondent was to submit to testing every six months for two years. Â Id. Â After every test, the results were to be reported to the Court.Â  Id.Â  Respondent filed a petition for reinstatement from this suspension in January of 2002.
Later that same month, the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) notified the Court of a new disciplinary matter involving Respondent.Â  ODC alleged that Respondent failed to comply with the terms of his definite suspension and had committed misconduct by (1) failing to submit reports of substance abuse testing to the Court as required[1] and (2) pleading guilty to a string of alcohol related offenses occurring between October 1998 and May 1999.Â  In particular, Respondent pled guilty to:

  
    
      
        a.  
         Three (3) counts of driving under the influence, fourth offense and above, in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 56-5-2930, 56-5-2940 (1991);
      
      
        b. 
         Two (2) counts of driving under suspension, in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-1-460 (1991);
      
      
        c. 
         One (1) count of violation of the Habitual Traffic Offender Law, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 56-1-1020, 56-1-1100 (Supp. 2004); and
      
      
        d.
         One (1) count of leaving the scene of an accident, in violation ofÂ  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-1220 (1991).
      
    
  

The Panel found that Respondent violated Rule 8.4 of the Rules of Professional Conduct (criminal act reflecting adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness, or fitness as a lawyer in other respects) and the following Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement: Rule 7(a)(1) (violating the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 7(a)(3) (willfully violating a valid order of the Supreme Court); Rule 7(a)(4) (conviction of a crime of moral turpitude or a serious crime); Rule 7(a)(5) (engaging in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law); and Rule 7(a)(7) (willfully violating a valid order issued by a court of this state).Â  The Panel recommended that Respondent be indefinitely suspended from the practice of law, retroactive to the date of his 1996 definite suspension, and that Respondent pay the costs of this action.[2]
Issues
Respondent accepts the Panelâ€™s findings and conclusions, but disagrees with the recommended sanction of an indefinite suspension.Â  Respondent asks the Court to impose a definite suspension for less than nine months so that he can seek reinstatement pursuant to Rule 32 of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the alternative, Respondent requests that the Court (1) waive the requirement that any future petition for reinstatement be referred to the Committee on Character and Fitness per Rule 33(d), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, and (2) permit his reinstatement without fulfilling the requirements of Rule 33(f)(8), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR (an attorney who has been disbarred or indefinitely suspended must take and pass the Bar Examination, take and pass the Multistate Professional Responsibility Exam, and complete the Bridge the Gap program). 
Respondent additionally requests that the Court allow reinstatement from his 1996 suspension in the same manner.Â  Respondent asks that the Court consider these unusual requests in light of his intention to immediately retire from the practice of law; an intention driven by Respondentâ€™s extremely poor health.[3]
Law/Analysis
The South Carolina Supreme Court possesses the ultimate responsibility of determining sanctions in attorney disciplinary matters.Â  In re Rushton, 286 S.C. 543, 544, 335 S.E.2d 238, 238 (1985).Â  In this case, the Court must note that several of the crimes involved are felonies under South Carolina law. Â Violation of the Habitual Traffic Offender Law is a felony. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-1-1100 (Supp. 2004).Â  Additionally, DUI fourth offense and above carries a minimum prison sentence of one year[4], and is therefore a felony.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-1-2030(14) (Supp. 2004).Â  In the case of Respondent, these convictions represent not Respondentâ€™s first, second, or third DUI arrests, but at least the fourth, fifth, and sixth occasions on which Respondent elected to drive while under the influence of alcohol.Â  
This Court has imposed varying degrees of sanctions in cases involving a DUI conviction.Â  Looking at existing case law, Respondentâ€™s disciplinary history, and the serious nature of the offenses for which Respondent was convicted, we find that the proper sanction is an indefinite suspension retroactive to the date of Respondentâ€™s 1996 definite suspension.Â  Should Respondent desire to gain readmission to the practice of law, he must proceed according to Rule 33(d), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR (unless otherwise directed by the Supreme Court, the petition for reinstatement shall be referred to the Committee on Character and Fitness), and Rule 33(f)(8), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR (an attorney who has been disbarred or indefinitely suspended must take and pass the Bar Examination, take and pass the Multistate Professional Responsibility Exam, and complete the Bridge the Gap program).Â  
Because Respondent has not satisfied the above requirements, we decline to address the issue of Respondentâ€™s petition for reinstatement from the 1996 definite suspension.
Conclusion
We are deeply saddened by the current state of Respondentâ€™s health.Â  However, we cannot ignore the serious nature of the conduct here at issue, nor can we simply overlook the fact that Respondent has twice before been sanctioned for attorney misconduct, including being disbarred from the practice of law.Â  Accordingly, we concur in the recommended sanction of the Panel and order that Respondent be indefinitely suspended from the practice of law, retroactive to the date of his 1996 definite suspension, and that Respondent pay the costs of this action.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, Respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
INDEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL,
C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.



[1] Court records showed that results for only nine of the fifteen required substance abuse tests were submitted. Â Eventually, the Panel concluded that all required tests were in fact performed and that Respondent had merely failed to ensure that the remaining six test results were submitted to the Court.Â  
[2] The Panelâ€™s award of costs has not been contested.Â  See In re Yarborough, 348 S.C. 243, 249, 559 S.E.2d 836, 839-840 (2002) (holding that failure to take exception to the Panelâ€™s report constitutes an acceptance of the report).Â  
[3] Respondent is seriously ill, is undergoing treatment, and has a poor prognosis.Â  
[4] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2940(4) (1991).

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Charleston Municipal Court Judge
Joseph S. Mendelsohn, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26058
Submitted July 6, 2005 - Filed October 24, 2005

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Robert E. Bogan, both of Columbia, for The Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
Coming B. Gibbs, Jr., of Gibbs & Holmes, and Donald H. Howe of Howe & Wyndham, both of Charleston, for respondent.Â Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a letter of caution, admonition, or public reprimand pursuant to Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  The facts as set forth in the Agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Respondent is a municipal court judge for the City of Charleston.Â  At approximately 9:15 p.m. on November 8, 2003, respondent was arrested for driving under the influence (DUI) in Mount Pleasant.Â  Respondent was also charged with having an open container in his vehicle in violation of South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 61-6-4020 (Supp. 2004).Â  Â 
Respondent was transported to the Mount Pleasant Police Department for paperwork and administration of a Datamaster test.Â  While there, respondent learned that, under procedures established by the Mount Pleasant Chief Municipal Judge, the bond for DUI was $1,002.00, but that bond could not be posted at that time.Â  Instead, under the established procedures, Judge Mendelsohn would be transferred to the Charleston County Detention Facility where he would remain until a bond hearing could be held the next morning at approximately 8:00 a.m.Â  
Respondent knew the Mount Pleasant procedure was not the same as the procedure used in Charleston.Â  In Charleston, an arrestee can post the preset bond and be released without having to wait for a bond hearing.Â  Respondent believed the Mount Pleasant procedure was illegal and questioned the arresting officer, sergeant, and a lieutenant.Â  
Respondent was allowed to use the telephone.Â  He called a Mount Pleasant municipal judge, again questioned the cityâ€™s procedure, and asked the judge to speak with the sergeant about the bond policy.Â  After speaking with the sergeant, the Mount Pleasant judge explained the policy to respondent.Â Â  
After first attempting to telephone another Charleston County magistrate, respondent contacted Charleston County Magistrate James B. Gosnell, Jr.Â  Magistrate Gosnell was unfamiliar with the Mount Pleasant bond procedure.Â  Â 
Magistrate Gosnell asked the Mount Pleasant lieutenant why respondent could not be released.Â  After the lieutenant explained the procedure, Magistrate Gosnell remarked that he would go to the bond court and conduct a bond hearing for respondent that night.Â  Magistrate Gosnell asked that respondent be brought directly to bond court rather than first being booked into the detention center.Â  The lieutenant refused to bypass the standard booking procedure, stating respondent would be booked like any other defendant. The lieutenant then advised the arresting officer that Magistrate Gosnell would be at the Charleston County Detention Center to conduct a bond hearing.Â  
Magistrate Gosnell met the arresting officer and respondent at the detention center.Â  At some point, Magistrate Gosnell took possession of the ticket, placed a â€œbond hearingâ€ stamp on the back, and entered the amount of $1,002.00.Â  Magistrate Gosnell communicated his setting of the bond to the Mount Pleasant Chief Judge and asked the judge to indicate his approval of the bond.Â  The Mount Pleasant Chief Judge called the Charleston County Detention Center and was advised that officers were in possession of a valid bond set by Magistrate Gosnell.Â  The Mount Pleasant Chief Judge told the officers that, since a bond had been set, the bond procedure he had established did not apply.Â  Respondent was released from the Charleston County Detention Center at approximately 2:30 a.m.Â  
Respondent represents his contact with Magistrate Gosnell and others was only for the purpose of determining the validity of the Mount Pleasant bond procedure, which he believed to be illegal, and was not to obtain preferential treatment or to be excused from the established procedure.Â  Respondent acknowledges, however, that his contact with other judges concerning his ability to post bond has the appearance of seeking preferential treatment.Â  
Respondent further represents he did not ask Magistrate Gosnell to set a bond outside the established procedure.Â  Respondent asserts that, although he did have personal contact with Magistrate Gosnell, he was not aware of all of Magistrate Gosnellâ€™s actions because he was involved in the booking process at the detention center and, at some point, was placed in a cell.Â  
Additionally, respondent represents his recollection is cloudy inasmuch as he was under the influence of alcohol.Â  Respondent contends he has no personal knowledge as to the individual actions and conversations of Magistrate Gosnell and others and that he learned of their activities only after the complaint in this matter was filed.Â  However, for purposes of this Agreement, respondent does not dispute the allegations.Â  
Respondent agreed to and did forfeit bond on the DUI and open liquor offenses.Â  
To the best of ODCâ€™s knowledge, respondent has been forthright and cooperative in this matter.Â  
LAW
Respondent used his judicial office to evade the policies of the arresting jurisdiction in order to obtain a non-scheduled bond hearing and early release from jail.Â  His misconduct violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon
2 (judge shall avoid impropriety and the appearance of impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall respect and comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary); and Canon 2B (judge shall not lend the prestige of his judicial office to advance the judgeâ€™s private interests).Â  By violating the Code of Judicial Conduct, respondent has also violated Rule 7(a)(1) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR (it shall be ground for discipline for a judge to violate the Code of Judicial Conduct).Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION 
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and issue a public reprimand. Â Accordingly, respondent is hereby reprimanded for his misconduct.Â  
 PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
